text: I would like to poke at this idea some more. I'd be interested in thoughts on what happened in the early days of reprogrammable electronic computers. FORTRAN was invented on a vacuum tube machine. Lisp was invented on a transistor machine. Both were invented before machines began using ICs. Both were invented something like 20+ years before the IBM PC was released. I doubt that Backus nor McCarthy had any idea that PCs were reasonably attainable and profitable.

text:
The move from tubes to transistors to ICs was just a reduction in size and energy consumption, and an increase in speed. The programming model never changed.

For short-term benefit it is always interesting to change as few aspects as possible when improving some technology. Put differently, re-use as much as you can. That's how we got stuck with early choices. And later ones, often bad.

I remember a discussion, long ago on Twitter, about the long-term fate of programming languages. The one hypotheses that withstood many attempts at refuting it states that once a language has a critical size of user base, it will stay around forever. Where "forever" of course means no more than a few decades for such a young technology. Everything that once was popular is still supported by someone. COBOL? Compilers are still available. My proposal for a counterexample was PL/1, but someone tracked down a supported compiler for it.
